issues.text: Whether the Municipal Council had power under the Madras Place of Public Resorts Act, 1888 to grant licence for exhibiting cinematographic films

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in quashing the three impeached resolutions said that the Municipal Council had nopower under the Madras Place of Public Resorts Act, 1888 because that Act ceased to be in force. The resolutions dated 11 June, 1970 and 18 June, 1970 were quashed on that ground.

issues.text: Whether section 256 of the Mysore Municipalities Act contemplated licence for installation of electric motors and oil engine for cinema exhibition

anchor.surface_text: The third impeached resolution dated 19 June, 1970 which granted permission to the third respondent for installation of electric motors and oil engine was quashed on the ground that nosuch licence was contemplated under the Mysore Municipalities Act. The High Court examined section 256 of the Mysore

issues.text: Whether the Central Ward Town Planning Scheme under Madras Town Planning Act, 1920 lapsed after 20 years

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Madras under the Madras Planning Act by an order dated 24 May, 1945 approved the Central Ward Town Planning Scheme in Udipi. Clause 15 of the Scheme provided that shops and business premises might be permitted only in places shown as reserved for the purpose. Business premises under the scheme means a building designed for use as an office or theatre or for any business purpose but does not include a petrol filling station, special industrial building, factory or workshop. The respondents contended in the High Court that the scheme was intended to be in force only for a period of 20 years and that it either lapsed or ceased to be in force after the expiration of 20 years. The High Court rejected the contention that the scheme lapsed after 20 years from 20 May, 1945.

issues.text: Whether sanctioning conversion of Kalyana Mantap into cinema theatre violated clauses 14 and 15 of the Town Planning Scheme

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further accepted the contention of the appellant that under clause 15 of the Scheme a cinema theatre which is regarded in the Scheme as business premises cannot be constructed in a place other than Badagapet Road, Hanuman Office Road and Post Office Road without the sanction of the responsible authority and without the previous approval of the Director of Town Planning. The High Court said that between the grant of permission to convert the building into a cinema theatre and the issue of interim order in Writ Petition No. 4904 of 1972 there was an interval of more than five months.

issues.text: Whether the appellant as resident has locus standi to challenge breach of town planning scheme without actual use of building as cinema or special damage

anchor.surface_text: The breach of a statutory duty created for the benefit of an individual or a class is a tortious act. Anyone who suffers special damage therefrom is entitled to recover damages. ... The appellant as the resident in the area has the right to compel the Municipality to perform duty imposed by the statute. The appellant has a right to insist on such performance of duty because he has an individual interest in the performance of the duty imposed by the Act that the scheme is not violated.

issues.text: Whether the Municipal Council's sanction for building contravening town planning scheme is ultra vires and amenable to judicial review

anchor.surface_text: Where the Municipality acts in excess of the powers conferred by the Act or abuses those powers then in those cases it is not exercising its jurisdiction irregularly or wrongly but it is usurping powers which it does not possess. ... If sanction is given to build by contravening a bye-law the jurisdiction of the Courts will be invoked on the ground that the approval by an authority of building plans which contravene the bye-laws made by that authority is illegal and inoperative

issues.text: Whether acquiescence, estoppel or money spent can validate excess of statutory power in the municipal resolution

anchor.surface_text: An excess of statutory power cannot be validated by acquiescence in or by the operation of an estoppel. The High Court was not correct in holding that though the impeached resolution sanctioning plan for conversion of building into a cinema was in violation of the Town Planning Scheme yet it could not be disturbed because the third respondent is likely to have spent money

issues.text: Whether appellant is barred by alternative remedies from challenging the resolution in writ petition

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondents contended that the appellant had pursued alternative remedies. One was the suit filed in 1970 for injunction against the third respondent to restrain installation of cinematographic apparatus and using the building as a cinema house. The other is Writ Petition No. 755 of 1973 challenging the order of the Deputy Commissioner dated 14 March, 1973 permitting exhibition of films. The suit does not seek any relief in respect of the impeached resolution which forms the subject-matter of this appeal. The writ petition also does not relate to any relief in that behalf. The contention of the respondents fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of section 256 does not cover cinema equipment installation; affirms High Court

holdings.text: Central Ward Town Planning Scheme under Madras Town Planning Act 1920 did not lapse after 20 years and remains in force

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Madras under the Madras Planning Act by an order dated 24 May, 1945 approved the Central Ward Town Planning Scheme in Udipi. Clause 15 of the Scheme provided that shops and business premises might be permitted only in places shown as reserved for the purpose. Business premises under the scheme means a building designed for use as an office or theatre or for any business purpose but does not include a petrol filling station, special industrial building, factory or workshop. The respondents contended in the High Court that the scheme was intended to be in force only for a period of 20 years and that it either lapsed or ceased to be in force after the expiration of 20 years. The High Court rejected the contention that the scheme lapsed after 20 years from 20 May, 1945.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent contention; affirms High Court that no 20-year lapse provision applies

holdings.text: Sanction for conversion of Kalyana Mantap into cinema theatre violates clauses 14 and 15 of Town Planning Scheme as site not on specified roads and no prior approval; resolution invalid and quashed

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further accepted the contention of the appellant that under clause 15 of the Scheme a cinema theatre which is regarded in the Scheme as business premises cannot be constructed in a place other than Badagapet Road, Hanuman Office Road and Post Office Road without the sanction of the responsible authority and without the previous approval of the Director of Town Planning. The High Court said that between the grant of permission to convert the building into a cinema theatre and the issue of interim order in Writ Petition No. 4904 of 1972 there was an interval of more than five months. ... Counsel for the appellant rightly submitted that the Town Planning Scheme forbade any cinema building at the place where the third respondent has asked for the cinema building and therefore the resolution is invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies scheme clauses restricting business premises like theatres to specific roads with approvals; residential area violated

holdings.text: Appellant as resident in area has locus standi to challenge breach of town planning scheme and compel performance of statutory duty without need for special damage or actual use as cinema

anchor.surface_text: The breach of a statutory duty created for the benefit of an individual or a class is a tortious act. Anyone who suffers special damage therefrom is entitled to recover damages. ... The appellant as the resident in the area has the right to compel the Municipality to perform duty imposed by the statute. The appellant has a right to insist on such performance of duty because he has an individual interest in the performance of the duty imposed by the Act that the scheme is not violated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Breach of duty for benefit of class (residents) gives right to enforce; individual interest in non-violation of scheme

holdings.text: Municipal sanction contravening town planning scheme is ultra vires, usurpation of power, illegal and amenable to judicial review; courts quash such acts

anchor.surface_text: Where the Municipality acts in excess of the powers conferred by the Act or abuses those powers then in those cases it is not exercising its jurisdiction irregularly or wrongly but it is usurping powers which it does not possess. ... If sanction is given to build by contravening a bye-law the jurisdiction of the Courts will be invoked on the ground that the approval by an authority of building plans which contravene the bye-laws made by that authority is illegal and inoperative

holdings.reasoning_summary: Excess/abuse of power is usurpation, not mere error; invokes court jurisdiction per precedents

holdings.text: Excess of statutory power cannot be validated by acquiescence, estoppel or money spent; High Court erred in not quashing resolution despite expenditure

anchor.surface_text: An excess of statutory power cannot be validated by acquiescence in or by the operation of an estoppel. The High Court was not correct in holding that though the impeached resolution sanctioning plan for conversion of building into a cinema was in violation of the Town Planning Scheme yet it could not be disturbed because the third respondent is likely to have spent money

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illegality incurable; equity does not validate ultra vires acts against statutory provisions

holdings.text: No bar by alternative remedies as suit and other writ do not challenge the impeached resolutions

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondents contended that the appellant had pursued alternative remedies. One was the suit filed in 1970 for injunction against the third respondent to restrain installation of cinematographic apparatus and using the building as a cinema house. The other is Writ Petition No. 755 of 1973 challenging the order of the Deputy Commissioner dated 14 March, 1973 permitting exhibition of films. The suit does not seek any relief in respect of the impeached resolution which forms the subject-matter of this appeal. The writ petition also does not relate to any relief in that behalf. The contention of the respondents fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative proceedings do not cover the specific resolutions challenged here

holdings.text: Municipality has no power to convert Kalyana Mantap-cum-Lecture Hall into cinema theatre; no statutory provision supports it

anchor.surface_text: The Municipality has no power to convert the lecture hall into a cinema theatre. No provision in the statute has been shown to support such an exercise of power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of statutory authorisation for conversion

holdings.text: The fourth impeached resolution dated 19 June 1970 sanctioning conversion into cinema theatre is quashed as without legal foundation and in violation of Town Planning Scheme

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, the appeal is accepted. The order of the High Court leaving resolution dated 19 June, 1970 being Annexure D to the Petition undisturbed is set aside. The resolution dated 19 June, 1970 being Annexure D to the Petition before the High Court is quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Culmination of all above reasons: violation, ultra vires, no validation

Clause 15 of the Scheme provided that shops and business premises might be permitted only in places shown as reserved for the purpose. Business premises under the scheme means a building designed for use as an office or theatre or for any business purpose but does not include a petrol filling station, special industrial building, factory or workshop. The respondents contended in the High Court that the scheme was intended to be in force only for a period of 20 years and that it either lapsed or ceased to be in force after the expiration of 20 years. The High Court rejected the contention that the scheme lapsed after 20 years from 20 May, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further accepted the contention of the appellant that under clause 15 of the Scheme a cinema theatre which is regarded in the Scheme as business premises cannot be constructed in a place other than Badagapet Road, Hanuman Office Road and Post Office Road without the sanction of the responsible authority and without the previous approval of the Director of Town Planning. The High Court said that between the grant of permission to convert the building into a cinema theatre and the issue of interim order in Writ Petition No. 4904 of 1972 there was an interval of more than five months. ... Counsel for the appellant rightly submitted that the Town Planning Scheme forbade any cinema building at the place where the third respondent has asked for the cinema building and therefore the resolution is invalid.
For the foregoing reasons, the appeal is accepted. The order of the High Court leaving resolution dated 19 June, 1970 being Annexure D to the Petition undisturbed is set aside. The

anchor.surface_text: The breach of a statutory duty created for the benefit of an individual or a class is a tortious act. Anyone who suffers special damage therefrom is entitled to recover damages. ... The appellant as the resident in the area has the right to compel the Municipality to perform duty imposed by the statute. The appellant has a right to insist on such performance of duty because he has an individual interest in the performance of the duty imposed by the Act that the scheme is not violated.
For the foregoing reasons, the appeal is accepted. The order of the High Court leaving resolution dated 19 June, 1970 being Annexure D to the Petition undisturbed is set aside. The

anchor.surface_text: Where the Municipality acts in excess of the powers conferred by the Act or abuses those powers then in those cases it is not exercising its jurisdiction irregularly or wrongly but it is usurping powers which it does not possess. ... If sanction is given to build by contravening a bye-law the jurisdiction of the Courts will be invoked on the ground that the approval by an authority of building plans which contravene the bye-laws made by that authority is illegal and inoperative
For the foregoing reasons, the appeal is accepted. The order of the High Court leaving resolution dated 19 June, 1970 being Annexure D to the Petition undisturbed is set aside. The

anchor.surface_text: An excess of statutory power cannot be validated by acquiescence in or by the operation of an estoppel. The High Court was not correct in holding that though the impeached resolution sanctioning plan for conversion of building into a cinema was in violation of the Town Planning Scheme yet it could not be disturbed because the third respondent is likely to have spent money

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the respondents contended that the appellant had pursued alternative remedies. One was the suit filed in 1970 for injunction against the third respondent to restrain installation of cinematographic apparatus and using the building as a cinema house. The other is Writ Petition No. 755 of 1973 challenging the order of the Deputy Commissioner dated 14 March, 1973 permitting exhibition of films. The suit does not seek any relief in respect of the impeached resolution which forms the subject-matter of this appeal. The writ petition also does not relate to any relief in that behalf. The contention of the respondents fails.
For the foregoing reasons, the appeal is accepted. The order of the High Court leaving resolution dated 19 June, 1970 being Annexure D to the Petition undisturbed is set aside. The
